0. D. K. SONG BOOK
The Hopkins Song Book, which has been compiled by the Omicron Delta Kappa Society, and is now in press, is yet another proof
of the steady growth of the University. For years the publication of
such a book has been discussed only to be abandoned because deemed
impractical.
The finished book will be a credit to Hopkins. No time nor
of
necessary expense has been spared. Rather than run the risk
,
having it appear cheap, an expensive cover has been provided
making it necessary to charge $1.25 a copy. In its final form, however, the book is one of which we may all be proud.

Cornell is second with 19 representatives, among them the president of the conference, Don R.
Almy, a lawyer of 46 Cedar street,
N .Y. U. is third with 11.
Illinois is the first of the more
distant universities with 8, while
Yale and Michigan follow with 7,

More than 200 college fraternity
men in all will be present.
The interfraternity Conference,
the advisory council of practically
all of the country's men's college
fraternities, will discuss a number of problems at American colleges at its tIvo-day convention.

OUR CHAMPIONSHIP TEAM AND
THE GOLD FOOTBALLS

For the first time since nineteen
fifteen Johns Hopkins has a State's
championship football team, one of
the best it has ever had, and one
which should go down in its history. This team. has given us a
good chance to attain a real place
in athletics, and it is certainly up
to those interested in the University to see that the record of its
achievement be remembered and
profited by.

DR. ANDREWS TO ADDRESS THE
SCIENTIFIC SOCIETY

Dr. E. A. Andrews, professor of
zoology, at this university, will deliver a lecture next Tuesday, December the sixth, before the Scientific Society. The subject of Dr.
Andrews' lecture will be the Bottle Animalcule, a micro-organism
which inhabits the waters of nearly
all parts of the world, and grows
in a form similar to that of a bottle. The meeting of the society will
be held at 4.15 in the large lecture
room No. 110, in the Mechanical Engineering Building. All
members of the faculty and students interested in this subject are
invited to attend the lecture.

DR. ANDREWS TO ADDRESS THE
SCIENTIFIC SOCIETY

Dr. E. A. Andrews, professor of
zoology, at this university, will deliver a lecture next Tuesday, December the sixth, before the Scientific Society. The subject of Dr.
Andrews' lecture will be the Bottle Animalcule, a micro-organism
which inhabits the waters of nearly
all parts of the world, and grows
in a form similar to that of a bottle. The meeting of the society will
be held at 4.15 in the large lecture
room No. 110, in the Mechanical Engineering Building. All
members of the faculty and students interested in this subject are
invited to attend the lecture.
